trans-unit.source: Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Learn how to troubleshoot an Azure web app by using remote debugging, tracing, and logging tools that are built in to Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to troubleshoot an Azure web app by using remote debugging, tracing, and logging tools that are built in to Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Troubleshoot a web app in Azure App Service using Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to use Visual Studio tools that help debug a web app while it runs in <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, by running in <link><linkText>debug mode</linkText><title></title></link> remotely or by viewing application logs and web server logs.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to use Visual Studio tools that help debug a web app while it runs in <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, by running in <link><linkText>debug mode</linkText><title></title></link> remotely or by viewing application logs and web server logs.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn:
trans-unit.target: You'll learn:

trans-unit.source: Which Azure web app management functions are available in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Which Azure web app management functions are available in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: How to use Visual Studio remote view to make quick changes in a remote web app.
trans-unit.target: How to use Visual Studio remote view to make quick changes in a remote web app.

trans-unit.source: How to run debug mode remotely while a project is running in Azure, both for a web app and for a WebJob.
trans-unit.target: How to run debug mode remotely while a project is running in Azure, both for a web app and for a WebJob.

trans-unit.source: How to create application trace logs and view them while the application is creating them.
trans-unit.target: How to create application trace logs and view them while the application is creating them.

trans-unit.source: How to view web server logs, including detailed error messages and failed request tracing.
trans-unit.target: How to view web server logs, including detailed error messages and failed request tracing.

trans-unit.source: How to send diagnostic logs to an Azure Storage account and view them there.
trans-unit.target: How to send diagnostic logs to an Azure Storage account and view them there.

trans-unit.source: If you have Visual Studio Ultimate, you can also use <link><linkText>IntelliTrace</linkText><title></title></link> for debugging.
trans-unit.target: If you have Visual Studio Ultimate, you can also use <link><linkText>IntelliTrace</linkText><title></title></link> for debugging.

trans-unit.source: IntelliTrace is not covered in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: IntelliTrace is not covered in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This tutorial works with the development environment, web project, and Azure web app that you set up in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial works with the development environment, web project, and Azure web app that you set up in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For the WebJobs sections, you'll need the application that you create in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK[getstartedwj]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For the WebJobs sections, you'll need the application that you create in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK[getstartedwj]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The code samples shown in this tutorial are for a C# MVC web application, but the troubleshooting procedures are the same for Visual Basic and Web Forms applications.
trans-unit.target: The code samples shown in this tutorial are for a C# MVC web application, but the troubleshooting procedures are the same for Visual Basic and Web Forms applications.

trans-unit.source: Remote debugging requires Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2012 with Update 4.
trans-unit.target: Remote debugging requires Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2012 with Update 4.

trans-unit.source: The remote debugging and Server Explorer features for WebJobs require Visual Studio 2013 Update 4 or later.
trans-unit.target: The remote debugging and Server Explorer features for WebJobs require Visual Studio 2013 Update 4 or later.

trans-unit.source: The other features shown in the tutorial also work in Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web, and Visual Studio 2012 Express for Web.
trans-unit.target: The other features shown in the tutorial also work in Visual Studio 2013 Express for Web, and Visual Studio 2012 Express for Web.

trans-unit.source: The streaming logs feature only works for applications that target .NET Framework 4 or later.
trans-unit.target: The streaming logs feature only works for applications that target .NET Framework 4 or later.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Web app configuration and management
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Web app configuration and management

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides access to a subset of the web app management functions and configuration settings available in the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides access to a subset of the web app management functions and configuration settings available in the <link><linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In this section you'll see what's available.
trans-unit.target: In this section you'll see what's available.

trans-unit.source: If you aren't already signed in to Azure in Visual Studio, click the Connect to Azure button in Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: If you aren't already signed in to Azure in Visual Studio, click the Connect to Azure button in Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to install a management certificate that enables access to your account.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to install a management certificate that enables access to your account.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to install a certificate, right-click the Azure node in Server Explorer, and then click Manage Subscriptions in the context menu.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to install a certificate, right-click the Azure node in Server Explorer, and then click Manage Subscriptions in the context menu.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage Azure Subscriptions dialog box, click the Certificates tab, and then click Import.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage Azure Subscriptions dialog box, click the Certificates tab, and then click Import.

trans-unit.source: Follow the directions to download and then import a subscription file (also called a .publishsettings file) for your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Follow the directions to download and then import a subscription file (also called a .publishsettings file) for your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you download a subscription file, save it to a folder outside your source code directories (for example, in the Downloads folder), and then delete it once the import has completed.
trans-unit.target: If you download a subscription file, save it to a folder outside your source code directories (for example, in the Downloads folder), and then delete it once the import has completed.

trans-unit.source: A malicious user who gains access to the subscription file can edit, create, and delete your Azure services.
trans-unit.target: A malicious user who gains access to the subscription file can edit, create, and delete your Azure services.

trans-unit.source: For more information about connecting to Azure resources from Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about connecting to Azure resources from Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, expand Azure, and then expand Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, expand Azure, and then expand Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the node for the web app that you created in Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted], and then click View Settings.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the node for the web app that you created in Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted], and then click View Settings.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View Settings in Server Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View Settings in Server Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Azure Web App tab appears, and you can see there the web app management and configuration tasks that are available in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Web App tab appears, and you can see there the web app management and configuration tasks that are available in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Web App window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Web App window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you'll be using the logging and tracing drop-downs.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you'll be using the logging and tracing drop-downs.

trans-unit.source: You'll also use remote debugging but you'll use a different method to enable it.
trans-unit.target: You'll also use remote debugging but you'll use a different method to enable it.

trans-unit.source: For information about the App Settings and Connection Strings boxes in this window, see <link><linkText>Azure Web Apps: How Application Strings and Connection Strings Work</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about the App Settings and Connection Strings boxes in this window, see <link><linkText>Azure Web Apps: How Application Strings and Connection Strings Work</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to perform a web app management task that can't be done in this window, you can click Full Web App Settings to open a browser window to the management portal.
trans-unit.target: If you want to perform a web app management task that can't be done in this window, you can click Full Web App Settings to open a browser window to the management portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to Configure Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to Configure Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Access web app files in Server Explorer
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Access web app files in Server Explorer

trans-unit.source: You typically deploy a web project with the customErrors flag in the Web.config file set to On or RemoteOnly, which means you don't get a helpful error message when something goes wrong.
trans-unit.target: You typically deploy a web project with the customErrors flag in the Web.config file set to On or RemoteOnly, which means you don't get a helpful error message when something goes wrong.

trans-unit.source: For many errors all you get is a page like one of the following ones.
trans-unit.target: For many errors all you get is a page like one of the following ones.

trans-unit.source: Server Error in '/' Application:
trans-unit.target: Server Error in '/' Application:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: An error occurred:
trans-unit.target: An error occurred:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The website cannot display the page
trans-unit.target: The website cannot display the page

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Unhelpful error page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Frequently the easiest way to find the cause of the error is to enable detailed error messages, which the first of the preceding screenshots explains how to do.
trans-unit.target: Frequently the easiest way to find the cause of the error is to enable detailed error messages, which the first of the preceding screenshots explains how to do.

trans-unit.source: That requires a change in the deployed Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: That requires a change in the deployed Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: You could edit the Web.config file in the project and redeploy the project, or create a Web.config transform and deploy a debug build, but there's a quicker way: in Solution Explorer you can directly view and edit files in the remote web app by using the remote view feature.
trans-unit.target: You could edit the Web.config file in the project and redeploy the project, or create a Web.config transform and deploy a debug build, but there's a quicker way: in Solution Explorer you can directly view and edit files in the remote web app by using the remote view feature.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, expand Azure, expand App Service, expand the resource group that your web app is located in, and then expand the node for your web app.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, expand Azure, expand App Service, expand the resource group that your web app is located in, and then expand the node for your web app.

trans-unit.source: You see nodes that give you access to the web app's content files and log files.
trans-unit.target: You see nodes that give you access to the web app's content files and log files.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Files node, and double-click the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Files node, and double-click the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open Web.config</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open Web.config</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio opens the Web.config file from the remote web app and shows [Remote] next to the file name in the title bar.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio opens the Web.config file from the remote web app and shows [Remote] next to the file name in the title bar.

trans-unit.source: Add the following line to the system.web element:
trans-unit.target: Add the following line to the system.web element:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Edit Web.config</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Edit Web.config</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Refresh the browser that is showing the unhelpful error message, and now you get a detailed error message, such as the following example:
trans-unit.target: Refresh the browser that is showing the unhelpful error message, and now you get a detailed error message, such as the following example:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Detailed error message</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Detailed error message</linkText>

trans-unit.source: (The error shown was created by adding the line shown in red to Views\Home\Index.cshtml.)
trans-unit.target: (The error shown was created by adding the line shown in red to Views\Home\Index.cshtml.)

trans-unit.source: Editing the Web.config file is only one example of scenarios in which the ability to read and edit files on your Azure web app make troubleshooting easier.
trans-unit.target: Editing the Web.config file is only one example of scenarios in which the ability to read and edit files on your Azure web app make troubleshooting easier.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Remote debugging web apps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Remote debugging web apps

trans-unit.source: If the detailed error message doesn't provide enough information, and you can't re-create the error locally, another way to troubleshoot is to run in debug mode remotely.
trans-unit.target: If the detailed error message doesn't provide enough information, and you can't re-create the error locally, another way to troubleshoot is to run in debug mode remotely.

trans-unit.source: You can set breakpoints, manipulate memory directly, step through code, and even change the code path.
trans-unit.target: You can set breakpoints, manipulate memory directly, step through code, and even change the code path.

trans-unit.source: Remote debugging does not work in Express editions of Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Remote debugging does not work in Express editions of Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This section shows how to debug remotely using the project you create in <link><linkText>Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This section shows how to debug remotely using the project you create in <link><linkText>Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Open the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs.

trans-unit.source: Delete the About() method and insert the following code in its place.
trans-unit.target: Delete the About() method and insert the following code in its place.

trans-unit.source: Set a breakpoint on the ViewBag.Message line.
trans-unit.target: Set a breakpoint on the ViewBag.Message line.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project, and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Profile drop-down list, select the same profile that you used in Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted].
trans-unit.target: In the Profile drop-down list, select the same profile that you used in Getting started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted].

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab, and change Configuration to Debug, and then click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab, and change Configuration to Debug, and then click Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish in debug mode</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish in debug mode</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After deployment finishes and your browser opens to the Azure URL of your web app, close the browser.
trans-unit.target: After deployment finishes and your browser opens to the Azure URL of your web app, close the browser.

trans-unit.source: For Visual Studio 2013: In Server Explorer expand Azure, expand Web Apps, right-click your web app, and click Attach Debugger.
trans-unit.target: For Visual Studio 2013: In Server Explorer expand Azure, expand Web Apps, right-click your web app, and click Attach Debugger.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Attach debugger</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Attach debugger</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The browser automatically opens to your home page running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The browser automatically opens to your home page running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.

trans-unit.source: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.
trans-unit.target: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent times within the next 48 hours when you start debugging again there won't be a delay.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent times within the next 48 hours when you start debugging again there won't be a delay.

trans-unit.source: For Visual Studio 2012 with Update 4:<html></html><html></html>
trans-unit.target: For Visual Studio 2012 with Update 4:<html></html><html></html>

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, go to Settings > Application settings for your web app, and then scroll down to the Debugging section.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, go to Settings > Application settings for your web app, and then scroll down to the Debugging section.

trans-unit.source: Set Remote Debugging to On, and set Remote Visual Studio Version to 2012.
trans-unit.target: Set Remote Debugging to On, and set Remote Visual Studio Version to 2012.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Debug menu, click Attach to Process.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Debug menu, click Attach to Process.

trans-unit.source: In the Qualifier box, enter the URL for your web app, without the http:// prefix.
trans-unit.target: In the Qualifier box, enter the URL for your web app, without the http:// prefix.

trans-unit.source: Select Show processes from all users.
trans-unit.target: Select Show processes from all users.

trans-unit.source: When you're prompted for credentials, enter the user name and password that has permissions to deploy content to the web app.
trans-unit.target: When you're prompted for credentials, enter the user name and password that has permissions to deploy content to the web app.

trans-unit.source: To get these credentials, go to the Dashboard tab for your web app in the management portal and click Download the publish profile.
trans-unit.target: To get these credentials, go to the Dashboard tab for your web app in the management portal and click Download the publish profile.

trans-unit.source: Open the file in a text editor, and you'll find the user name and password after the first occurrences of userName= and userPWD=.
trans-unit.target: Open the file in a text editor, and you'll find the user name and password after the first occurrences of userName= and userPWD=.

trans-unit.source: When the processes appear in the Available Processes table, select w3wp.exe, and then click Attach.
trans-unit.target: When the processes appear in the Available Processes table, select w3wp.exe, and then click Attach.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser to the URL of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser to the URL of your web app.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.

trans-unit.source: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.
trans-unit.target: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent times within the next 48 hours when you start debugging again there won't be a delay.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent times within the next 48 hours when you start debugging again there won't be a delay.

trans-unit.source: Click About in the menu.
trans-unit.target: Click About in the menu.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio stops on the breakpoint, and the code is running in Azure, not on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio stops on the breakpoint, and the code is running in Azure, not on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Hover over the currentTime variable to see the time value.
trans-unit.target: Hover over the currentTime variable to see the time value.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View variable in debug mode running in Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View variable in debug mode running in Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The time you see is the Azure server time, which may be in a different time zone than your local computer.
trans-unit.target: The time you see is the Azure server time, which may be in a different time zone than your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Enter a new value for the currentTime variable, such as "Now running in Azure".
trans-unit.target: Enter a new value for the currentTime variable, such as "Now running in Azure".

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to continue running.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to continue running.

trans-unit.source: The About page running in Azure displays the new value that you entered into the currentTime variable.
trans-unit.target: The About page running in Azure displays the new value that you entered into the currentTime variable.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>About page with new value</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>About page with new value</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> Remote debugging WebJobs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> Remote debugging WebJobs

trans-unit.source: This section shows how to debug remotely using the project and web app you create in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This section shows how to debug remotely using the project and web app you create in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The features shown on in this section are available only in Visual Studio 2013 with Update 4.
trans-unit.target: The features shown on in this section are available only in Visual Studio 2013 with Update 4.

trans-unit.source: Remote debugging only works with continuous WebJobs.
trans-unit.target: Remote debugging only works with continuous WebJobs.

trans-unit.source: Scheduled and on-demand WebJobs don't support debugging.
trans-unit.target: Scheduled and on-demand WebJobs don't support debugging.

trans-unit.source: Open the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK[getstartedwj]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Open the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK[getstartedwj]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the ContosoAdsWebJob project, open Functions.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the ContosoAdsWebJob project, open Functions.cs.

trans-unit.source: Set a breakpoint on the first statement in the GnerateThumbnail method.
trans-unit.target: Set a breakpoint on the first statement in the GnerateThumbnail method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set breakpoint</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set breakpoint</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the web project (not the WebJob project), and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the web project (not the WebJob project), and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Profile drop-down list, select the same profile that you used in Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK.
trans-unit.target: In the Profile drop-down list, select the same profile that you used in Get Started with the Azure WebJobs SDK.

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab, and change Configuration to Debug, and then click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab, and change Configuration to Debug, and then click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio deploys the web and WebJob projects, and your browser opens to the Azure URL of your web app.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio deploys the web and WebJob projects, and your browser opens to the Azure URL of your web app.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer expand Azure > Web Apps > your web app > WebJobs > Continuous, and then right-click ContosoAdsWebJob.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer expand Azure > Web Apps > your web app > WebJobs > Continuous, and then right-click ContosoAdsWebJob.

trans-unit.source: Click Attach Debugger.
trans-unit.target: Click Attach Debugger.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Attach debugger</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Attach debugger</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The browser automatically opens to your home page running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The browser automatically opens to your home page running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait 20 seconds or so while Azure sets up the server for debugging.

trans-unit.source: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.
trans-unit.target: This delay only happens the first time you run in debug mode on a web app.

trans-unit.source: The next time you attach the debugger there won't be a delay, if you do it within 48 hours.
trans-unit.target: The next time you attach the debugger there won't be a delay, if you do it within 48 hours.

trans-unit.source: In the web browser that is opened to the Contoso Ads home page, create a new ad.
trans-unit.target: In the web browser that is opened to the Contoso Ads home page, create a new ad.

trans-unit.source: Creating an ad causes a queue message to be created, which will be picked up by the WebJob and processed.
trans-unit.target: Creating an ad causes a queue message to be created, which will be picked up by the WebJob and processed.

trans-unit.source: When the WebJobs SDK calls the function to process the queue message, the code will hit your breakpoint.
trans-unit.target: When the WebJobs SDK calls the function to process the queue message, the code will hit your breakpoint.

trans-unit.source: When the debugger breaks at your breakpoint, you can examine and change variable values while the program is running the cloud.
trans-unit.target: When the debugger breaks at your breakpoint, you can examine and change variable values while the program is running the cloud.

trans-unit.source: In the following illustration the debugger shows the contents of the blobInfo object that was passed to the GenerateThumbnail method.
trans-unit.target: In the following illustration the debugger shows the contents of the blobInfo object that was passed to the GenerateThumbnail method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>blobInfo object in debugger</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>blobInfo object in debugger</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to continue running.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to continue running.

trans-unit.source: The GenerateThumbnail method finishes creating the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: The GenerateThumbnail method finishes creating the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: In the browser, refresh the Index page and you see the thumbnail.
trans-unit.target: In the browser, refresh the Index page and you see the thumbnail.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press SHIFT+F5 to stop debugging.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press SHIFT+F5 to stop debugging.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsWebJob node and click View Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click the ContosoAdsWebJob node and click View Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with your Azure credentials, and then click the WebJob name to go to the page for your WebJob.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with your Azure credentials, and then click the WebJob name to go to the page for your WebJob.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click ContosoAdsWebJob</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click ContosoAdsWebJob</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Dashboard shows that the GenerateThumbnail function executed recently.
trans-unit.target: The Dashboard shows that the GenerateThumbnail function executed recently.

trans-unit.source: (The next time you click View Dashboard, you don't have to sign in, and the browser goes directly to the page for your WebJob.)
trans-unit.target: (The next time you click View Dashboard, you don't have to sign in, and the browser goes directly to the page for your WebJob.)

trans-unit.source: Click the function name to see details about the function execution.
trans-unit.target: Click the function name to see details about the function execution.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Function details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Function details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If your function wrote logs, you could click ToggleOutput to see them.
trans-unit.target: If your function wrote logs, you could click ToggleOutput to see them.

trans-unit.source: Notes about remote debugging
trans-unit.target: Notes about remote debugging

trans-unit.source: Running in debug mode in production is not recommended.
trans-unit.target: Running in debug mode in production is not recommended.

trans-unit.source: If your production web app is not scaled out to multiple server instances, debugging will prevent the web server from responding to other requests.
trans-unit.target: If your production web app is not scaled out to multiple server instances, debugging will prevent the web server from responding to other requests.

trans-unit.source: If you do have multiple web server instances, when you attach to the debugger you'll get a random instance, and you have no way to ensure that subsequent browser requests will go to that instance.
trans-unit.target: If you do have multiple web server instances, when you attach to the debugger you'll get a random instance, and you have no way to ensure that subsequent browser requests will go to that instance.

trans-unit.source: Also, you typically don't deploy a debug build to production, and compiler optimizations for release builds might make it impossible to show what is happening line by line in your source code.
trans-unit.target: Also, you typically don't deploy a debug build to production, and compiler optimizations for release builds might make it impossible to show what is happening line by line in your source code.

trans-unit.source: For troubleshooting production problems, your best resource is application tracing and web server logs.
trans-unit.target: For troubleshooting production problems, your best resource is application tracing and web server logs.

trans-unit.source: Avoid long stops at breakpoints when remote debugging.
trans-unit.target: Avoid long stops at breakpoints when remote debugging.

trans-unit.source: Azure treats a process that is stopped for longer than a few minutes as an unresponsive process, and shuts it down.
trans-unit.target: Azure treats a process that is stopped for longer than a few minutes as an unresponsive process, and shuts it down.

trans-unit.source: While you're debugging, the server is sending data to Visual Studio, which could affect bandwidth charges.
trans-unit.target: While you're debugging, the server is sending data to Visual Studio, which could affect bandwidth charges.

trans-unit.source: For information about bandwidth rates, see <link><linkText>Azure Pricing</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about bandwidth rates, see <link><linkText>Azure Pricing</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the debug attribute of the compilation element in the Web.config file is set to true.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the debug attribute of the compilation element in the Web.config file is set to true.

trans-unit.source: It is set to true by default when you publish a debug build configuration.
trans-unit.target: It is set to true by default when you publish a debug build configuration.

trans-unit.source: If you find that the debugger won't step into code that you want to debug, you might have to change the Just My Code setting.
trans-unit.target: If you find that the debugger won't step into code that you want to debug, you might have to change the Just My Code setting.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Restrict stepping to Just My Code</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Restrict stepping to Just My Code</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: A timer starts on the server when you enable the remote debugging feature, and after 48 hours the feature is automatically turned off.
trans-unit.target: A timer starts on the server when you enable the remote debugging feature, and after 48 hours the feature is automatically turned off.

trans-unit.source: This 48 hour limit is done for security and performance reasons.
trans-unit.target: This 48 hour limit is done for security and performance reasons.

trans-unit.source: You can easily turn the feature back on as many times as you like.
trans-unit.target: You can easily turn the feature back on as many times as you like.

trans-unit.source: We recommend leaving it disabled when you are not actively debugging.
trans-unit.target: We recommend leaving it disabled when you are not actively debugging.

trans-unit.source: You can manually attach the debugger to any process, not only the web app process (w3wp.exe).
trans-unit.target: You can manually attach the debugger to any process, not only the web app process (w3wp.exe).

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to use debug mode in Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Debugging in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to use debug mode in Visual Studio, see <link><linkText>Debugging in Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Diagnostic logs overview
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Diagnostic logs overview

trans-unit.source: An ASP.NET application that runs in an Azure web app can create the following kinds of logs:
trans-unit.target: An ASP.NET application that runs in an Azure web app can create the following kinds of logs:

trans-unit.source: Application tracing logs
trans-unit.target: Application tracing logs

trans-unit.source: The application creates these logs by calling methods of the <link><linkText>System.Diagnostics.Trace</linkText><title></title></link> class.
trans-unit.target: The application creates these logs by calling methods of the <link><linkText>System.Diagnostics.Trace</linkText><title></title></link> class.

trans-unit.source: Web server logs
trans-unit.target: Web server logs

trans-unit.source: The web server creates a log entry for every HTTP request to the web app.
trans-unit.target: The web server creates a log entry for every HTTP request to the web app.

trans-unit.source: Detailed error message logs
trans-unit.target: Detailed error message logs

trans-unit.source: The web server creates an HTML page with some additional information for failed HTTP requests (those that result in status code 400 or greater).
trans-unit.target: The web server creates an HTML page with some additional information for failed HTTP requests (those that result in status code 400 or greater).

trans-unit.source: Failed request tracing logs
trans-unit.target: Failed request tracing logs

trans-unit.source: The web server creates an XML file with detailed tracing information for failed HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: The web server creates an XML file with detailed tracing information for failed HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: The web server also provides an XSL file to format the XML in a browser.
trans-unit.target: The web server also provides an XSL file to format the XML in a browser.

trans-unit.source: Logging affects web app performance, so Azure gives you the ability to enable or disable each type of log as needed.
trans-unit.target: Logging affects web app performance, so Azure gives you the ability to enable or disable each type of log as needed.

trans-unit.source: For application logs, you can specify that only logs above a certain severity level should be written.
trans-unit.target: For application logs, you can specify that only logs above a certain severity level should be written.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new web app, by default all logging is disabled.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new web app, by default all logging is disabled.

trans-unit.source: Logs are written to files in a LogFiles folder in the file system of your web app and are accessible via FTP.
trans-unit.target: Logs are written to files in a LogFiles folder in the file system of your web app and are accessible via FTP.

trans-unit.source: Web server logs and application logs can also be written to an Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Web server logs and application logs can also be written to an Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can retain a greater volume of logs in a storage account than is possible in the file system.
trans-unit.target: You can retain a greater volume of logs in a storage account than is possible in the file system.

trans-unit.source: You're limited to a maximum of 100 megabytes of logs when you use the file system.
trans-unit.target: You're limited to a maximum of 100 megabytes of logs when you use the file system.

trans-unit.source: (File system logs are only for short-term retention.
trans-unit.target: (File system logs are only for short-term retention.

trans-unit.source: Azure deletes old log files to make room for new ones after the limit is reached.)
trans-unit.target: Azure deletes old log files to make room for new ones after the limit is reached.)

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Create and view application trace logs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Create and view application trace logs

trans-unit.source: In this section you'll do the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: In this section you'll do the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: Add tracing statements to the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Add tracing statements to the web project that you created in <link><linkText>Get started with Azure and ASP.NET[getstarted]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: View the logs when you run the project locally.
trans-unit.target: View the logs when you run the project locally.

trans-unit.source: View the logs as they are generated by the application running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: View the logs as they are generated by the application running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to create application logs in WebJobs, see <link><linkText>How to work with Azure queue storage using the WebJobs SDK - How to write logs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to create application logs in WebJobs, see <link><linkText>How to work with Azure queue storage using the WebJobs SDK - How to write logs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following instructions for viewing logs and controlling how they're stored in Azure apply also to application logs created by WebJobs.
trans-unit.target: The following instructions for viewing logs and controlling how they're stored in Azure apply also to application logs created by WebJobs.

trans-unit.source: Add tracing statements to the application
trans-unit.target: Add tracing statements to the application

trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs, and replace the file contents with the following code in order to add Trace statements and a using statement for System.Diagnostics:

trans-unit.target: View the tracing output locally

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run the application in debug mode.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run the application in debug mode.

trans-unit.source: The default trace listener writes all trace output to the Output window, along with other Debug output.
trans-unit.target: The default trace listener writes all trace output to the Output window, along with other Debug output.

trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to view trace output in a web page, without compiling in debug mode.

trans-unit.target: Open the application Web.config file (the one located in the project folder) and add a element at the end of the file just before the closing element:

trans-unit.target: The WebPageTraceListener lets you view trace output by browsing to /trace.axd.

trans-unit.source: Add a trace element under in the Web.config file, such as the following example:
trans-unit.target: Add a trace element under in the Web.config file, such as the following example:

trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.target: In the address bar of the browser window, add trace.axd to the URL, and then press Enter (the URL will be similar to http://localhost:53370/trace.axd).

trans-unit.target: On the Application Trace page, click View Details on the first line (not the BrowserLink line).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>trace.axd</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>trace.axd</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Request Details page appears, and in the Trace Information section you see the output from the trace statements that you added to the Index method.
trans-unit.target: The Request Details page appears, and in the Trace Information section you see the output from the trace statements that you added to the Index method.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>trace.axd</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>trace.axd</linkText>

trans-unit.source: By default, trace.axd is only available locally.
trans-unit.target: By default, trace.axd is only available locally.

trans-unit.source: If you wanted to make it available from a remote web app, you could add localOnly="false" to the trace element in the Web.config file, as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: If you wanted to make it available from a remote web app, you could add localOnly="false" to the trace element in the Web.config file, as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: However, enabling trace.axd in a production web app is generally not recommended for security reasons, and in the following sections you'll see an easier way to read tracing logs in an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: However, enabling trace.axd in a production web app is generally not recommended for security reasons, and in the following sections you'll see an easier way to read tracing logs in an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: View the tracing output in Azure
trans-unit.target: View the tracing output in Azure

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the web project and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the web project and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: After Visual Studio publishes your update, it opens a browser window to your home page (assuming you didn't clear Destination URL on the Connection tab).
trans-unit.target: After Visual Studio publishes your update, it opens a browser window to your home page (assuming you didn't clear Destination URL on the Connection tab).

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click your web app and select View Streaming Logs.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click your web app and select View Streaming Logs.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View Streaming Logs in context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View Streaming Logs in context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Output window shows that you are connected to the log-streaming service, and adds a notification line each minute that goes by without a log to display.
trans-unit.target: The Output window shows that you are connected to the log-streaming service, and adds a notification line each minute that goes by without a log to display.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View Streaming Logs in context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View Streaming Logs in context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that shows your application home page, click Contact.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that shows your application home page, click Contact.

trans-unit.source: Within a few seconds the output from the error-level trace you added to the Contact method appears in the Output window.
trans-unit.target: Within a few seconds the output from the error-level trace you added to the Contact method appears in the Output window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Error trace in Output window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Error trace in Output window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio is only showing error-level traces because that is the default setting when you enable the log monitoring service.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio is only showing error-level traces because that is the default setting when you enable the log monitoring service.

trans-unit.source: When you create a new Azure web app, all logging is disabled by default, as you saw when you opened the settings page earlier:
trans-unit.target: When you create a new Azure web app, all logging is disabled by default, as you saw when you opened the settings page earlier:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Application Logging off</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Application Logging off</linkText>

trans-unit.source: However, when you selected View Streaming Logs, Visual Studio automatically changed Application Logging(File System) to Error, which means error-level logs get reported.
trans-unit.target: However, when you selected View Streaming Logs, Visual Studio automatically changed Application Logging(File System) to Error, which means error-level logs get reported.

trans-unit.source: In order to see all of your tracing logs, you can change this setting to Verbose.
trans-unit.target: In order to see all of your tracing logs, you can change this setting to Verbose.

trans-unit.source: When you select a severity level lower than error, all logs for higher severity levels are also reported.
trans-unit.target: When you select a severity level lower than error, all logs for higher severity levels are also reported.

trans-unit.source: So when you select verbose, you also see information, warning, and error logs.
trans-unit.target: So when you select verbose, you also see information, warning, and error logs.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, right-click the web app, and then click View Settings as you did earlier.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, right-click the web app, and then click View Settings as you did earlier.

trans-unit.source: Change Application Logging (File System) to Verbose, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: Change Application Logging (File System) to Verbose, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Setting trace level to Verbose</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Setting trace level to Verbose</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that is now showing your Contact page, click Home, then click About, and then click Contact.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that is now showing your Contact page, click Home, then click About, and then click Contact.

trans-unit.source: Within a few seconds, the Output window shows all of your tracing output.
trans-unit.target: Within a few seconds, the Output window shows all of your tracing output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Verbose trace output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Verbose trace output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this section you enabled and disabled logging by using Azure web app settings.
trans-unit.target: In this section you enabled and disabled logging by using Azure web app settings.

trans-unit.source: You can also enable and disable trace listeners by modifying the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: You can also enable and disable trace listeners by modifying the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: However, modifying the Web.config file causes the app domain to recycle, while enabling logging via the web app configuration doesn't do that.
trans-unit.target: However, modifying the Web.config file causes the app domain to recycle, while enabling logging via the web app configuration doesn't do that.

trans-unit.source: If the problem takes a long time to reproduce, or is intermittent, recycling the app domain might "fix" it and force you to wait until it happens again.
trans-unit.target: If the problem takes a long time to reproduce, or is intermittent, recycling the app domain might "fix" it and force you to wait until it happens again.

trans-unit.source: Enabling diagnostics in Azure doesn't do this, so you can start capturing error information immediately.
trans-unit.target: Enabling diagnostics in Azure doesn't do this, so you can start capturing error information immediately.

trans-unit.source: Output window features
trans-unit.target: Output window features

trans-unit.source: The Azure Logs tab of the Output Window has several buttons and a text box:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Logs tab of the Output Window has several buttons and a text box:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Logs tab buttons</linkText>

trans-unit.target: These perform the following functions:

trans-unit.target: Clear the Output window.

trans-unit.target: Enable or disable word wrap.

trans-unit.target: Start or stop monitoring logs.

trans-unit.target: Specify which logs to monitor.

trans-unit.target: Filter logs based on a search string or a regular expression.

trans-unit.target: If you enter a search string or regular expression, Visual Studio filters logging information at the client.

trans-unit.target: That means you can enter the criteria after the logs are displayed in the Output window and you can change filtering criteria without having to regenerate the logs.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>View web server logs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>View web server logs

trans-unit.source: Web server logs record all HTTP activity for the web app.
trans-unit.target: Web server logs record all HTTP activity for the web app.

trans-unit.source: In order to see them in the Output window you have to enable them for the web app and tell Visual Studio that you want to monitor them.
trans-unit.target: In order to see them in the Output window you have to enable them for the web app and tell Visual Studio that you want to monitor them.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Web App Configuration tab that you opened from Server Explorer, change Web Server Logging to On, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Web App Configuration tab that you opened from Server Explorer, change Web Server Logging to On, and then click Save.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enable web server logging</linkText>

trans-unit.target: In the Output Window, click the Specify which Azure logs to monitor button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Specify which Azure logs to monitor</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Specify which Azure logs to monitor</linkText>

trans-unit.target: In the Azure Logging Options dialog box, select Web server logs, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Monitor web server logs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Monitor web server logs</linkText>

trans-unit.target: In the browser window that shows the web app, click Home, then click About, and then click Contact.

trans-unit.source: The application logs generally appear first, followed by the web server logs.
trans-unit.target: The application logs generally appear first, followed by the web server logs.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait a while for the logs to appear.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait a while for the logs to appear.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web server logs in Output window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web server logs in Output window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: By default, when you first enable web server logs by using Visual Studio, Azure writes the logs to the file system.
trans-unit.target: By default, when you first enable web server logs by using Visual Studio, Azure writes the logs to the file system.

trans-unit.source: As an alternative, you can use the management portal to specify that web server logs should be written to a blob container in a storage account.
trans-unit.target: As an alternative, you can use the management portal to specify that web server logs should be written to a blob container in a storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the site diagnostics section in How to Configure Web Sites.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the site diagnostics section in How to Configure Web Sites.

trans-unit.source: If you use the management portal to enable web server logging to an Azure storage account, and then disable logging in Visual Studio, when you re-enable logging in Visual Studio your storage account settings are restored.
trans-unit.target: If you use the management portal to enable web server logging to an Azure storage account, and then disable logging in Visual Studio, when you re-enable logging in Visual Studio your storage account settings are restored.

trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>View detailed error message logs

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Download file system logs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Download file system logs

trans-unit.target: Any logs that you can monitor in the Output window can also be downloaded as a .zip file.

trans-unit.source: Detailed error message logs are in .html files in the LogFiles\DetailedErrors folder.
trans-unit.target: Detailed error message logs are in .html files in the LogFiles\DetailedErrors folder.

trans-unit.source: (The deployments folder is for files created by source control publishing; it doesn't have anything related to Visual Studio publishing.
trans-unit.target: (The deployments folder is for files created by source control publishing; it doesn't have anything related to Visual Studio publishing.

trans-unit.source: The Git folder is for traces related to source control publishing and the log file streaming service.)
trans-unit.target: The Git folder is for traces related to source control publishing and the log file streaming service.)

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>View storage logs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>View storage logs

trans-unit.source: Application tracing logs can also be sent to an Azure storage account, and you can view them in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Application tracing logs can also be sent to an Azure storage account, and you can view them in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: To do that you'll create a storage account, enable storage logs in the management portal, and view them in the Logs tab of the Azure Web App window.
trans-unit.target: To do that you'll create a storage account, enable storage logs in the management portal, and view them in the Logs tab of the Azure Web App window.

trans-unit.source: You can send logs to any or all of three destinations:
trans-unit.target: You can send logs to any or all of three destinations:

trans-unit.source: The file system.
trans-unit.target: The file system.

trans-unit.source: Storage account tables.
trans-unit.target: Storage account tables.

trans-unit.source: Storage account blobs.
trans-unit.target: Storage account blobs.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a different severity level for each destination.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a different severity level for each destination.

trans-unit.source: Tables make it easy to view details of logs online, and they support streaming; you can query logs in tables and see new logs as they are being created.
trans-unit.target: Tables make it easy to view details of logs online, and they support streaming; you can query logs in tables and see new logs as they are being created.

trans-unit.source: Blobs make it easy to download logs in files and to analyze them using HDInsight, because HDInsight knows how to work with blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Blobs make it easy to download logs in files and to analyze them using HDInsight, because HDInsight knows how to work with blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Hadoop and MapReduce in Data Storage Options (Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Hadoop and MapReduce in Data Storage Options (Building Real-World Cloud Apps with Azure).

trans-unit.source: You currently have file system logs set to verbose level; the following steps walk you through setting up information level logs to go to storage account tables.
trans-unit.target: You currently have file system logs set to verbose level; the following steps walk you through setting up information level logs to go to storage account tables.

trans-unit.source: Information level means all logs created by calling Trace.TraceInformation, Trace.TraceWarning, and Trace.TraceError will be displayed, but not logs created by calling Trace.WriteLine.
trans-unit.target: Information level means all logs created by calling Trace.TraceInformation, Trace.TraceWarning, and Trace.TraceError will be displayed, but not logs created by calling Trace.WriteLine.

trans-unit.source: Storage accounts offer more storage and longer-lasting retention for logs compared to the file system.
trans-unit.target: Storage accounts offer more storage and longer-lasting retention for logs compared to the file system.

trans-unit.source: Another advantage of sending application tracing logs to storage is that you get some additional information with each log that you don't get from file system logs.
trans-unit.target: Another advantage of sending application tracing logs to storage is that you get some additional information with each log that you don't get from file system logs.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Storage under the Azure node, and then click Create Storage Account.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Storage under the Azure node, and then click Create Storage Account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Storage Account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Storage Account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create Storage Account dialog, enter a name for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Storage Account dialog, enter a name for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The name must be must be unique (no other Azure storage account can have the same name).
trans-unit.target: The name must be must be unique (no other Azure storage account can have the same name).

trans-unit.source: If the name you enter is already in use you'll get a chance to change it.
trans-unit.target: If the name you enter is already in use you'll get a chance to change it.

trans-unit.source: The URL to access your storage account will be {name}.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: The URL to access your storage account will be {name}.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: Set the Region or Affinity Group drop-down list to the region closest to you.
trans-unit.target: Set the Region or Affinity Group drop-down list to the region closest to you.

trans-unit.source: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter will host your storage account.
trans-unit.target: This setting specifies which Azure datacenter will host your storage account.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial your choice won't make a noticeable difference, but for a production web app you want your web server and your storage account to be in the same region to minimize latency and data egress charges.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial your choice won't make a noticeable difference, but for a production web app you want your web server and your storage account to be in the same region to minimize latency and data egress charges.

trans-unit.source: The web app (which you'll create later) should run in a region as close as possible to the browsers accessing your web app in order to minimize latency.
trans-unit.target: The web app (which you'll create later) should run in a region as close as possible to the browsers accessing your web app in order to minimize latency.

trans-unit.source: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.
trans-unit.target: Set the Replication drop-down list to Locally redundant.

trans-unit.source: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.
trans-unit.target: When geo-replication is enabled for a storage account, the stored content is replicated to a secondary datacenter to enable failover to that location in case of a major disaster in the primary location.

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication can incur additional costs.

trans-unit.source: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.
trans-unit.target: For test and development accounts, you generally don't want to pay for geo-replication.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Create, manage, or delete a storage account</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Azure Web App window, click the Logs tab, and then click Configure Logging in Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Azure Web App window, click the Logs tab, and then click Configure Logging in Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure logging</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure logging</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This opens the Configure tab in the management portal for your web app.
trans-unit.target: This opens the Configure tab in the management portal for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Another way to get here is to click the Web Apps tab, click your web app, and then click the Configure tab.
trans-unit.target: Another way to get here is to click the Web Apps tab, click your web app, and then click the Configure tab.

trans-unit.source: In the management portal Configure tab, scroll down to the application diagnostics section, and then change Application Logging (Table Storage) to On.
trans-unit.target: In the management portal Configure tab, scroll down to the application diagnostics section, and then change Application Logging (Table Storage) to On.

trans-unit.source: Change Logging Level to Information.
trans-unit.target: Change Logging Level to Information.

trans-unit.source: Click Manage Table Storage.
trans-unit.target: Click Manage Table Storage.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Manage TableStorage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Manage TableStorage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Manage table storage for application diagnostics box, you can choose your storage account if you have more than one.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage table storage for application diagnostics box, you can choose your storage account if you have more than one.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new table or use an existing one.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new table or use an existing one.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Manage table storage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Manage table storage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Manage table storage for application diagnostics box click the check mark to close the box.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage table storage for application diagnostics box click the check mark to close the box.

trans-unit.source: In the management portal Configure tab, click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the management portal Configure tab, click Save.

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that displays the application web app, click Home, then click About, and then click Contact.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that displays the application web app, click Home, then click About, and then click Contact.

trans-unit.source: The logging information produced by browsing these web pages will be written to the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The logging information produced by browsing these web pages will be written to the storage account.

trans-unit.source: In the Logs tab of the Azure Web App window in Visual Studio, click Refresh under Diagnostic Summary.
trans-unit.target: In the Logs tab of the Azure Web App window in Visual Studio, click Refresh under Diagnostic Summary.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Refresh</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Refresh</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Diagnostic Summary section shows logs for the last 15 minutes by default.
trans-unit.target: The Diagnostic Summary section shows logs for the last 15 minutes by default.

trans-unit.source: You can change the period to see more logs.
trans-unit.target: You can change the period to see more logs.

trans-unit.source: (If you get a "table not found" error, verify that you browsed to the pages that do the tracing after you enabled Application Logging (Storage) and after you clicked Save.)
trans-unit.target: (If you get a "table not found" error, verify that you browsed to the pages that do the tracing after you enabled Application Logging (Storage) and after you clicked Save.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Storage logs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage logs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice that in this view you see Process ID and Thread ID for each log, which you don't get in the file system logs.
trans-unit.target: Notice that in this view you see Process ID and Thread ID for each log, which you don't get in the file system logs.

trans-unit.source: You can see additional fields by viewing the Azure storage table directly.
trans-unit.target: You can see additional fields by viewing the Azure storage table directly.

trans-unit.source: Click View all application logs.
trans-unit.target: Click View all application logs.

trans-unit.source: The trace log table appears in the Azure storage table viewer.
trans-unit.target: The trace log table appears in the Azure storage table viewer.

trans-unit.source: (If you get a "sequence contains no elements" error, open Server Explorer, expand the node for your storage account under the Azure node, and then right-click Tables and click Refresh.)
trans-unit.target: (If you get a "sequence contains no elements" error, open Server Explorer, expand the node for your storage account under the Azure node, and then right-click Tables and click Refresh.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Storage logs in table view</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage logs in table view</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This view shows additional fields you don't see in any other views.
trans-unit.target: This view shows additional fields you don't see in any other views.

trans-unit.source: This view also enables you to filter logs by using special Query Builder UI for constructing a query.
trans-unit.target: This view also enables you to filter logs by using special Query Builder UI for constructing a query.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Working with Table Resources - Filtering Entities in <link><linkText>Browsing Storage Resources with Server Explorer</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Working with Table Resources - Filtering Entities in <link><linkText>Browsing Storage Resources with Server Explorer</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To look at the details for a single row, double-click one of the rows.
trans-unit.target: To look at the details for a single row, double-click one of the rows.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Trace table in Server Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Trace table in Server Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>View failed request tracing logs
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>View failed request tracing logs

trans-unit.source: Failed request tracing logs are useful when you need to understand the details of how IIS is handling an HTTP request, in scenarios such as URL rewriting or authentication problems.
trans-unit.target: Failed request tracing logs are useful when you need to understand the details of how IIS is handling an HTTP request, in scenarios such as URL rewriting or authentication problems.

trans-unit.source: Azure web apps use the same failed request tracing functionality that has been available with IIS 7.0 and later.
trans-unit.target: Azure web apps use the same failed request tracing functionality that has been available with IIS 7.0 and later.

trans-unit.source: You don't have access to the IIS settings that configure which errors get logged, however.
trans-unit.target: You don't have access to the IIS settings that configure which errors get logged, however.

trans-unit.source: When you enable failed request tracing, all errors are captured.
trans-unit.target: When you enable failed request tracing, all errors are captured.

trans-unit.source: You can enable failed request tracing by using Visual Studio, but you can't view them in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can enable failed request tracing by using Visual Studio, but you can't view them in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: These logs are XML files.
trans-unit.target: These logs are XML files.

trans-unit.source: The streaming log service only monitors files that are deemed readable in plain text mode: .txt, .html, and .log files.
trans-unit.target: The streaming log service only monitors files that are deemed readable in plain text mode: .txt, .html, and .log files.

trans-unit.source: You can view failed request tracing logs in a browser directly via FTP or locally after using an FTP tool to download them to your local computer.
trans-unit.target: You can view failed request tracing logs in a browser directly via FTP or locally after using an FTP tool to download them to your local computer.

trans-unit.source: In this section you'll view them in a browser directly.
trans-unit.target: In this section you'll view them in a browser directly.

trans-unit.source: In the Configuration tab of the Azure Web App window that you opened from Server Explorer, change Failed Request Tracing to On, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the Configuration tab of the Azure Web App window that you opened from Server Explorer, change Failed Request Tracing to On, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enable failed request tracing</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enable failed request tracing</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the address bar of the browser window that shows the web app, add an extra character to the URL and click Enter to cause a 404 error.
trans-unit.target: In the address bar of the browser window that shows the web app, add an extra character to the URL and click Enter to cause a 404 error.

trans-unit.source: This causes a failed request tracing log to be created, and the following steps show how to view or download the log.
trans-unit.target: This causes a failed request tracing log to be created, and the following steps show how to view or download the log.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in the Configuration tab of the Azure Web App window, click Open in Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in the Configuration tab of the Azure Web App window, click Open in Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the management portal blade for your web app, click All settings > Deployment credentials, and then click Reset your deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the management portal blade for your web app, click All settings > Deployment credentials, and then click Reset your deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: Enter a new user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Enter a new user name and password.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New FTP user name and password</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New FTP user name and password</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the management portal Dashboard tab press F5 to refresh the page, and then scroll down to where you see Deployment / FTP User.
trans-unit.target: In the management portal Dashboard tab press F5 to refresh the page, and then scroll down to where you see Deployment / FTP User.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the user name has the web app name prefixed to it.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the user name has the web app name prefixed to it.

trans-unit.source: When you log in, you have to use this full user name with the web app name prefixed to it as shown here.
trans-unit.target: When you log in, you have to use this full user name with the web app name prefixed to it as shown here.

trans-unit.source: In a new browser window, go to the URL that is shown under FTP Host Name in the Dashboard tab of the management portal page for your web app.
trans-unit.target: In a new browser window, go to the URL that is shown under FTP Host Name in the Dashboard tab of the management portal page for your web app.

trans-unit.source: FTP Host Name is located near Deployment / FTP User in the Quick Glance section.
trans-unit.target: FTP Host Name is located near Deployment / FTP User in the Quick Glance section.

trans-unit.source: Log in using the FTP credentials that you created earlier (including the web app name prefix for the user name).
trans-unit.target: Log in using the FTP credentials that you created earlier (including the web app name prefix for the user name).

trans-unit.source: The browser shows the root folder of the web app.
trans-unit.target: The browser shows the root folder of the web app.

trans-unit.source: Open the LogFiles folder.
trans-unit.target: Open the LogFiles folder.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open LogFiles folder</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open LogFiles folder</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Open the folder that is named W3SVC plus a numeric value.
trans-unit.target: Open the folder that is named W3SVC plus a numeric value.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open W3SVC folder</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open W3SVC folder</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The folder contains XML files for any errors that have been logged after you enabled failed request tracing, and an XSL file that a browser can use to format the XML.
trans-unit.target: The folder contains XML files for any errors that have been logged after you enabled failed request tracing, and an XSL file that a browser can use to format the XML.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>W3SVC folder</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>W3SVC folder</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the XML file for the failed request that you want to see tracing information for.
trans-unit.target: Click the XML file for the failed request that you want to see tracing information for.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows part of the tracing information for a sample error.
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows part of the tracing information for a sample error.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Failed request tracing in browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Failed request tracing in browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Videos by Scott Hanselman and David Ebbo.
trans-unit.target: Videos by Scott Hanselman and David Ebbo.

trans-unit.source: For error logging, an alternative to writing your own tracing code is to use an open-source logging framework such as <link><linkText>ELMAH</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For error logging, an alternative to writing your own tracing code is to use an open-source logging framework such as <link><linkText>ELMAH</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Scott Hanselman's blog posts about ELMAH</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Scott Hanselman's blog posts about ELMAH</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Also, note that you don't have to use ASP.NET or System.Diagnostics tracing if you want to get streaming logs from Azure.
trans-unit.target: Also, note that you don't have to use ASP.NET or System.Diagnostics tracing if you want to get streaming logs from Azure.

trans-unit.source: The Azure web app streaming log service will stream any .txt, .html, or .log file that it finds in the LogFiles folder.
trans-unit.target: The Azure web app streaming log service will stream any .txt, .html, or .log file that it finds in the LogFiles folder.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you could create your own logging system that writes to the file system of the web app, and your file will be automatically streamed and downloaded.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you could create your own logging system that writes to the file system of the web app, and your file will be automatically streamed and downloaded.

trans-unit.source: All you have to do is write application code that creates files in the d:\home\logfiles folder.
trans-unit.target: All you have to do is write application code that creates files in the d:\home\logfiles folder.
